Award.AwardTitle: Cocycles over hyperbolic and partially hyperbolic systems
Award.AbstractNarration:
Cocycles play an important role in classical dynamics as well as in the theory of group actions. The main part of the proposed research is the study of cocycles over hyperbolic and partially hyperbolic diffeomorphisms. In this context important examples of linear cocycles are given by the differential of the diffeomorphism and by its restrictions to invariant sub-bundles of the tangent bundle. If the bundle is trivial the linear cocycle can be viewed as a cocycle with values in a matrix group. The PI will also study cocycles with values in other groups, including infinite dimensional ones. The PI plans to work on various problems in cohomology of cocycles. The questions in this area are motivated in part by problems in smooth dynamics and rigidity of hyperbolic and partially hyperbolic systems and group actions. The PI intends to use her recent results as well as the projected outcomes to further the research in these areas.

Dynamics is the area of mathematics that studies evolution of a system over time with an emphasis on describing its long term behavior. The systems under consideration come from mathematics, physics, and other sciences. Hyperbolic and partially hyperbolic systems have been one of the main objects of study in differentiable dynamics. Exponential contraction and expansion in these systems produce chaotic behavior, and understanding the complex structure of the system is an important goal. The derivative plays a crucial role in analysing these systems, and it gives an example of a cocycle over the system. Cocycles also appear naturally in linearized equations that relate two systems and thus are useful in the study of stability, rigidity, and classification of hyperbolic systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The theory of dynamical systems is a modern branch of mathematics which originated from the study of physical and mechanical problems. Its main objective is to describe how various abstract and real life systems evolve over time. The project was focused on systems with hyperbolic behavior, which are one of the central areas in smooth dynamics. These systems are characterized by exponential expansion in some directions and exponential contraction in other directions. 


Cocycles play a major role in the study of dynamical systems. For smooth systems, the derivative and related objects provide important examples and motivation. Other examples include random matrices and operators. The main objective of the project was to investigate cocycles over hyperbolic and partially hyperbolic dynamical systems. The emphasis was on non-commutative cocycles, such as cocycles with values in the group of real invertible d by d matrices, GL(d,R). The PI obtained important results on cohomology of GL(d,R)-valued cocycles, going beyond the case of compact or commutative groups. Moreover, the PI  extended these results to cocycles with values in  infinite dimensional groups of linear operators on Banach spaces. Further, the PI  obtained results for cocycles over partially hyperbolic systems. These are now the most general and definitive results in this area.


The PI advanced the theory of Lyapunov exponents  of cocycles, which describe exponential growth rates,by obtaining periodic approximation for infinite-dimensional setting as well as for cocycles over non-uniformly hyperbolic dynamical systems. This significantly extended the earlier approximation results and paved way for various results on cohomology of cocycles and the relation between the properties of a cocycle and its periodic data.


The theory of normal forms serves as a bridge between the study of the derivative cocycle and the properties of the nonlinear system. The PI significantly advanced the theory of non-stationary normal forms on leaves of uniformly and non-uniformly contracted foliations.  The previous results in this area already proved very useful in the study of dynamical systems exhibiting various forms of hyperbolicity, and the PI's results have potential for further applications.


The award resulted  in  8 papers in high-quality peer-reviewed journals.The PI also gave a number of talks on her research at conferences, colloquia and seminars.

The PI is a member of the Center for Dynamics and Geometry at Penn State. It is an active group consisting of faculty, postdocs, and graduate students. 


In 2013-2015 the PI served as the Interim Director of the MASS (Mathematics Advanced Study Semesters) program at Penn State. This is a semester-long program for a group of talented and motivated undergraduate students selected from U.S. colleges and universities. For majority of its participants, the program serves as a spring board to graduate studies in mathematics. The PI developed and taught a course “An Introduction to Dynamical Systems” for MASS students.


The PI is a member of the WIM (Women in Mathematics) group at Penn State. Its main objective  is to provide support and information to the women within the mathematics community at all levels. In particular, the PI is in charge of WIM scholarships that support female undergraduate students working on research projects in mathematics.
